isis.stitle: TSI 93-04-04 - Hydraulic Disc Brake Caliper Piston Condition

subjectgroup.subject: Hydraulic Disc Brake Caliper Piston Condition

geninfo.para: This TSI applies to all models with Hydraulic Brakes.

Disc brake pad wear should be checked as part of the preventative maintenance service and inspection or at least every 10,000 miles under normal operating conditions; more frequently under severe service conditions.
During disc pad replacement, all wheel end brake components and mountings should be thoroughly inspected and all needed repairs performed before new disc pads are installed.

Calipers should be rebuilt if the piston shows extensive damage (see Figure 3), the seal boot has failed or is damaged, or if the piston is sticking in the bore. If the boot has failed, the piston seal surface may become pitted or corroded.

svcproc.title: INSPECTION
svcproc.para: Some vehicles have phenolic (dark colored nonmetallic material) caliper pistons. It is important that these pistons be inspected for cracks, chips or gouges in the area that passes through the piston seal whenever the brake pads are replaced.
Figure 1 illustrates a phenolic piston that is in good condition and may be re-used.
No cracks, chips, gouges or any other damage which would contact the seal is allowed on the piston O.D.
Figure 2illustrates mechanical damage to the face of the piston. The metal insert is intact.
Cracks, chips and gouges may not extend into the piston seal area. The piston seal area is the area below the metal heat shield.
The phenolic piston in Figure 3shows excessive heat damage to the end of the piston that is in contact with the brake pad. The metal insert on the open end of the piston is also missing.
A piston in this condition should not be re-used.

svcproc.title: PISTON INSTALLATION
svcproc.para: Use a wire brush to remove any rust from the exposed end of the piston. Lubricate piston, seal and caliper bore with clean brake fluid. Assure that the seal is fully seated. Position dust boot and insert piston in bore. Apply firm steady pressure to piston, and guide it through the piston seal until bottomed in the caliper housing. Avoid using a C-clamp or pliers to compress piston. If strong resistance is felt, remove the piston and inspect the piston seal installation.

svcproc.title: NOISE SUPPRESSION
svcproc.para: A common complaint of disc brakes is brake "squeal". Metal to metal contact along with vibration are the most common causes. No rotor is perfectly true; so as the rotor turns, the brake pads vibrate. Contact between the metal backing plate of the brake pad against the piston creates a high pitched squeal.

Before installing the brake pads, coat the backside of the pad plates with a 1/16-inch coat of liquid Disc Brake Quiet, Part # ZDEM6-04. Allow 20-30 minutes curing time if room temperature is above 72 degrees. Allow longer curing time for temperatures below 72 degrees.
